Comment 2: 
maybe it is WorkAsIntended, but, in the C version (although not fully equivalent) below,
'n' is always the inner scope variable in statement 'int n = arr[n];'

int main(int argc, char* argv[])
{
	int n = 2;
	int arr[] = { 0, 5, 4, 3, 2};
	if( n > 1 )
	{
		int n = arr[n];
		printf("%d\n", n);
	}
	return 0;
}
